In Cazalla de la Sierra there used to be around 15 destileries, but only two remain today. Its quality was once certified by a Comitee of Cazalla producers, which dissapeared with the other destilleries. Nowadays, the quality is recognised based on the history of this product and its relation with the locality, keeping the traditional making. In fact, the name of Cazalla for these kind of drinks directly reffers to the municipality of Cazalla de la Sierra that once was the main producer of anis drinks. The production of Cazalla started as a complementary industry of wine making and thanks to the wild aniseed that grows in the region. Nonetheless, the vines from the region Sierra Norte de Sevilla and the produced wines are still a growing asset, producing quality wines under a PDO label.   The reference mountain chain of this VC is Sierra Morena. The reference mountain landscape of this VC is Cazalla de la Sierra. This MRL is located in a mid-mountain area with a mosaic landscape that combines dense forests with dehesa and agricultural fields. Therefore, the agricultural production is diverse in the region, combining crops with low-intensity livestock. The urban settlement has historic constructions and monuments from the XV and XVI centuries. The MRL is also well known by other artisanal products such as olive oil or dry-cured meat. High quality product with old tradition in the area. The important wine production that Cazalla de la Sierra had during the 15th and 16th centuries, resulted in the distillation of the leftovers in order to obtain the alcohol with which this drink began to be manufactured. Today there is a museum in the area to explore the history behind the local wines and spirits. The new product was the introduction of the cherry in the anis drinks. The marketing strategy is linked to the e-commerce.   Survive in a time when the consumption of anis and cherry drinks is less popular. Overall the type of challenge faced by this VC is Current.
